bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, December 5, 1922

div1.p: Hanson discusses his career options in Peru and Africa. He mentions the possibility of leaving public health.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, December 5, 1922
div1.opener:
Kris.
Hanson
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN EL PERU
OFICINA CENTRAL
Answered
Dec 10/22.
3014 Winfield Ave., Forest Park,
Baltimore, Md. December 5, 1922.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I feel rather guilty in taking up so much of your
valuable time by these letters of mine on purely personal matters, but I
appreciate your opinions and advice above that of othermen and for that you
have to suffer.

I have not yet been able to set my mind at rest on what I want to
do, or rather on what I ought to do. In regard to what I want to do there is
no question, but one can not always do what he wants to do and it becomes a
problem of choosing the least undesirable substitute; that is my present dilemma.
The Sioux City proposition has some very desirable features in that it would
be virgin territory in which to carry out the diphtheria work which Park of
New York has inaugurated with such apparently promising results. This feature
of the work seems to be very well done here, and I am at present helping out
to a certain extent on it.

Sioux City has for some time had a very much higher diphtheria rate t
than it should and it has occurred to me that a person who knows how to carry
of this work could (if the people would let him) go in and do a general immuni-
zation, after testing the children out by the Shick method, and in about two
years or less bring their diphtheria incidence down to practically nothing. The
difficulty in my way there is that they have some state law that one can not
be a Health Officer in Iowa or the Iowa cities unless he is licensed to prac-
tice and has actually been in the practice of medicine there for a certain
specified time. As far as I am concerned I am licenced in Wisconsin and Florida
but not in Iowa. Whether there is a way to get around this I do not yet know.
Going there however would mean the laying aside of all my tropical experience,
even to a greater extent than going to Florida in the private capacity of which
I have been thinking of late. The work there would be surgical pathology in
which cancer and other malignant conditions would take the lead. In addition
there would be a certain amount of blood work, bacteriology and vaccines etc.
Beyond that it would be what one would choose to put in the energy to make it.
The idea of leaving the public health career depresses me more than anything I
have contemplated so far. I have labored under the delusion that I was fairly
well established and that I had a training and experience which would be worth
something where there still is work to be done. In this connection I believe that
I would be of more value to Peru than to any other place that I know of. There
I know the conditions, the people and to a workable extent the language. It also
seems that the people there have more confidence in me than in any other place
outside of the medical department of the Panama Canal. For some reason the pro-
fession (doctors and inspectors) on the Zone seem to estimate my ability and
work very highly.

The political situation in Peru seems to be very uncertain. The
President and his cousin the “Ministro de Gobierno” have had a serious falling
out, to the extent that if is reported that Leguia-Martinez attempted to start
a revolution against Leguia, but the latter took him prisoner and what has
happened after that I do not know. This situation would mean that the present
executive will bee too busy trading and buying support to be able to fulfill
and promises to the health department. He has, however? put through and act in
this last congress which allows the president to run for reelection without
waiting for an intervening term as formerly. This means that he will probab-
ly succeed himself. The present finances however are said to be even more
stringent than when I left. The Government employees are having great diffi-
culty in collecting their wages which extends even to the peones. Under such
conditions I do not see that it is worth while going back.

As far as the I. H. B. is concerned I presume that the only chance
I would have had with them would have been to have gone to Mexico. May be
that I made a mistake in not taking the proposition which Dr. White made. It
however was contingent upon his making certain modifications in their plans
there which I am not certain that he could have put through. Even if he had
it probably would have been unpleasant on account of the relation with the
older men in the service. As for their African work it is difficult to know
what Dr. Rose has in mind if he does not take your advice. If he did and I
should be asked to go I quite agree that it would be better that it would be
preferable to have someone conduct the preliminary negociations and let me
take charge of the field work and the men. As you say one man could not do
both, in the beginning at least, or even later it were better if he did not
have much of the diplomatic work. That was not what I had in mind when I said
that the I.H.B. did not have many men to whom I would care to be subordinate.
I would want to have considerable to say about the makeup of the personnel,
and would like to have a limited few of my old staff with me, such as Dunn,
probably Guldstarnd, and Sainz would be worth taking.

At present I have an opportunity to do a bit of part time work
here which would bring in enough to reduce my expenses by about $150.00
per month, and still allow me to carry on some special studies in the special
lines I may wish to take up. The work would be in the diphtheria control
and immunixation, which in itself would be valuable experience. The only
objection to this is that if I am to take up the Jacksonville work it is
open now; the opportunity there probably will not again be what it is now
and if I do not take that I will be obliged to continue seeking “a living”
in public health work. A person should not think of a public health job as
“seeking a living”, it ought to be a very dignified career, as it has been
for many, and as it would be for many of us if we could work with men of
your type. Unfortunately there seem to be very few H.R. Carters, only one
at the present time.

You need not apologize for any of your letters. They are all full
of helpful information and guidance. I am preserving them all in my permanent
files. I know how busy you are and I do not want my personal affairs to
interfere too much with your great work.

It seems the decision which I shall be obliged to make within the
next few days will one which shall definitely determine what my future work
is to be. If it be Jacksonville, it will be the end of the public life, if
I stay on here through the year it will be a continuation of the public
health work. If I go to Jacksonville, Africa and all other positions of that
kind will be eliminated.

Martha and Virgil are asleep, otherwise they would join Mrs. Hanson
and myself in sending love to you and Laura.
